verses.text: Bring near to you Aaron your brother, and his sons with him, from among the Israelites, so that he may serve me as priest—Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar, the sons of Aaron.
verses.comment: God establishes the priesthood through Aaron and his sons, setting apart an ordained ministry. The idea of priesthood for the people is foundational to later Christian understanding of ministerial office and apostolic succession.

verses.text: Make holy garments for Aaron your brother, to give him glory and beauty.
verses.comment: The special priestly garments signify consecration, glory, and dignity. This typology is reflected in the vestments of later worship, emphasizing the sacredness of leadership in worship.

verses.text: Tell all the skilled people whom I have filled with a spirit of wisdom, that they are to make Aaron’s garments, to sanctify him, so that he may serve me as priest.
verses.comment: God inspires artisans for sacred work. The sanctification of Aaron parallels the way later Christian leaders are set apart and clothed for ministry, highlighting God’s initiative in creating order in worship.

verses.text: These are the garments they are to make: a breastpiece, an ephod, a robe, a tunic of checkered work, a turban, and a sash. Make holy garments for Aaron your brother and for his sons, so that they may serve me as priests.
verses.comment: Each garment has unique significance, symbolizing different aspects of spiritual service. The variety anticipates distinctive roles within worship, seen later in Christian liturgical traditions.

verses.text: They shall use gold, blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and fine linen.
verses.comment: Precious materials, fit for the presence of God, are prescribed. Such richness in worship and vestments continues in Christian practice, expressing reverence before God.

verses.text: They shall make the ephod of gold, blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and of fine twisted linen, skillfully worked.
verses.comment: The ephod is especially significant in priestly function. The blending of many colors points to unity in worship.

verses.text: It shall have two shoulder pieces attached at its two edges, so that it may be joined together.
verses.comment: The shoulder pieces reinforce the idea of bearing responsibility, prefiguring the carrying of God's people before Him, as Christ does as high priest in the New Testament.

verses.text: The skillfully woven band on the ephod, which is attached to it, shall be of one piece with it, made with gold, blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and fine twisted linen.
verses.comment: Unity of design speaks to the wholeness of God's service. The diversity of color unified in one band suggests spiritual unity among believers.

verses.text: Take two onyx stones, and engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel,
verses.comment: The high priest bears Israel before God continually. This foreshadows Christ interceding with the Father for the Church.

verses.text: Six of their names on one stone and six on the other, in the order of their birth.
verses.comment: Order is important in God’s plans. It also suggests the order Christ established among the apostles.

verses.text: As an engraver engraves a seal, so you shall engrave the two stones with the names of the sons of Israel. You shall enclose them in settings of gold.
verses.comment: Sealing and gold settings express permanence and dignity, like the lasting covenant God gives His people and the reverence of sacred objects.

verses.text: Set the two stones on the shoulder pieces of the ephod, as memorial stones for the sons of Israel, and Aaron shall bear their names before the Lord on his two shoulders as a remembrance.
verses.comment: Bearing the names on his shoulders, Aaron represents Israel to God. This prefigures Christ, the ultimate High Priest, carrying believers in His intercession (see Heb 7:25).

verses.text: You shall make settings of gold,
verses.comment: Gold represents purity and the preciousness of service to God.

verses.text: and two chains of pure gold twisted like cords, and you shall attach the chains to the gold settings.
verses.comment: Pure gold chains joining the memorial stones signify the enduring connection between God and His people.

verses.text: You shall make a breastpiece for judgment, skilled work; make it like the ephod—of gold, blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and of fine twisted linen.
verses.comment: The breastpiece is central for mediating judgment and guidance. This foreshadows Christ as the one who mediates between God and humanity (see 1 Tim 2:5).

verses.text: It shall be square and doubled, a span in length and a span in width.
verses.comment: The square shape and measured size symbolize completeness and orderliness in God's judgments.

verses.text: You shall set in it four rows of stones: the first row shall be a ruby, a topaz, and a beryl;
verses.comment: Each stone represents a tribe of Israel—precious before God. This symbolism appears again in Revelation, tying together God's covenant people.

verses.text: the second row a turquoise, a sapphire, and an emerald;
verses.comment: Diversity in stones reflects diversity among tribes, all cherished by God.

verses.text: the third row a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst;
verses.comment: These stones continue the theme of glory and sacredness in God's people.

verses.text: and the fourth row a chrysolite, an onyx, and a jasper. They shall be enclosed in gold settings.
verses.comment: Gold settings signify the value and security of God's people. The twelve stones and their arrangement echo the heavenly city in Revelation.

verses.text: The stones shall be according to the names of the twelve sons of Israel, engraved like seals, each with the name of one of the twelve tribes.
verses.comment: God’s relationship with His people is individualized and personal, as each tribe is called by name.

verses.text: Make for the breastpiece braided chains of pure gold, like cords.
verses.comment: Connections of gold cord reinforce the sacred unity of God’s people in worship.

verses.text: You shall make for the breastpiece two gold rings, and put the two rings on the two ends of the breastpiece.
verses.comment: Gold rings solidify structure—fitting for the steadfastness expected of those who intercede before God.

verses.text: Put the two braided chains of gold in the two rings at the ends of the breastpiece.
verses.comment: This detail maintains unity and beauty in the sacred vestment.

verses.text: Attach the other ends of the two cords to the two settings, and tie them to the shoulder pieces of the ephod at the front.
verses.comment: The breastpiece is front and center, emphasizing the importance of judgment and intercession before God.

verses.text: Make two gold rings and put them on the two ends of the breastpiece, on its inside edge next to the ephod.
verses.comment: Interior rings ensure the breastpiece remains securely attached during ministry.

verses.text: Make two more gold rings and attach them to the front of the ephod, below the shoulder pieces, close to its seam above the woven band of the ephod.
verses.comment: Precise attachment facilitates proper function—God cares about both detail and devotion.

verses.text: Bind the rings of the breastpiece to the rings of the ephod with a blue cord, so that the breastpiece will not come loose from the ephod.
verses.comment: Blue cord represents the heavens. The connection signifies the relationship between judgment and spiritual authority.

verses.text: Aaron shall bear the names of the sons of Israel in the breastpiece of judgment on his heart when he goes before the Lord, continually as a memorial before the Lord.
verses.comment: The high priest carries Israel on his heart—symbolic of Christ’s sacrificial love and His intercession for believers.

verses.text: In the breastpiece of judgment put the Urim and the Thummim, so that they may be on Aaron’s heart when he goes before the Lord. Thus Aaron shall bear the means of judgment for the sons of Israel on his heart before the Lord continually.
verses.comment: Urim and Thummim were means of discerning God's will, reserved for the high priest—anticipating the fullness of prophetic revelation found in Christ.

verses.text: Make the robe of the ephod entirely of blue yarn.
verses.comment: The robe’s heavenly blue color points to the divine origin of God's calling and the priest’s role as mediator.

verses.text: It shall have an opening for the head in the middle, with a woven edge around the opening, like the opening in a garment, so that it does not tear.
verses.comment: Garments without seams are more durable. The robe worn by Christ at His Passion was seamless (see John 19:23), symbolizing unity.

verses.text: On its hem make pomegranates of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, all around its hem, with golden bells between them all around.
verses.comment: Pomegranates symbolize fruitfulness; bells declare the priest’s approach—echoing the liturgical call to worship.

verses.text: Alternate a golden bell and a pomegranate, all around the hem of the robe.
verses.comment: Sound and bounty signify both the priest’s presence and the richness of God’s spiritual blessings.

verses.text: Aaron shall wear it when he ministers, and its sound will be heard when he goes into the Holy Place before the Lord and when he comes out, so that he may not die.
verses.comment: The bells announce the priest’s entrance, showing reverence and care in approaching God—necessary for mediation between God and man.

verses.text: Make a plate of pure gold and engrave on it, like the engraving of a seal, 'Holy to the Lord.'
verses.comment: 'Holy to the Lord' on gold emphasizes consecration. All worship leaders and acts should be set apart in holiness.

verses.text: Fasten it to a blue cord to put on the turban; it shall be on the front of the turban.
verses.comment: The insignia in front publicly demonstrates sacred calling, reflecting the spiritual authority of worship leaders.

verses.text: It shall be on Aaron’s forehead, and Aaron shall bear any guilt from the holy things that the Israelites consecrate as their holy gifts. It shall be on his forehead continually, that they may be accepted before the Lord.
verses.comment: The priest’s mediatorial role bears the people's guilt and seeks their acceptance before God. This aspect powerfully anticipates Christ’s atoning work.

verses.text: You shall weave the tunic of fine linen, and make a turban of fine linen, and you shall make a sash embroidered with needlework.
verses.comment: Fine linen is a symbol of purity and righteousness, qualities required in those who serve God.

verses.text: For Aaron’s sons you shall make tunics, and sashes, and turbans. You shall make them for glory and beauty.
verses.comment: All who serve inherit dignity and sacredness through special vestments—dignity given to all ministers of God.

verses.text: Put them on Aaron your brother and on his sons with him. Anoint them, ordain them, and consecrate them, so that they may serve me as priests.
verses.comment: Anointing and ordination are to be done by laying on of hands, setting apart men for lifelong priestly service. This lays the foundation for apostolic succession and the ministry of intercession.

verses.text: Make linen undergarments for them, to cover their naked bodies; they shall reach from the waist to the thighs.
verses.comment: Covering nakedness demonstrates modesty and purity for all ministers who approach God.

verses.text: Aaron and his sons must wear them whenever they enter the tent of meeting or approach the altar to minister in the Holy Place, so that they do not bring guilt or die. This shall be a perpetual statute for him and for his descendants after him.
verses.comment: These ordinances are intended to endure through generations, pointing toward the perpetual character of the Church's priestly ministry and sacramental worship.
